Expectation1: Communicate politely and professionally with customers
Situation1: Meeting the customer for handing over a package
Expectation2: Engage in spiritual study and reflection
Situation2: The nun has a quiet afternoon and plans to spend time in personal spiritual reading and contemplation.
Story: I had been looking forward to this afternoon all week—a rare stretch of quiet in the convent, set aside for spiritual reading and reflection. My Bible and journal waited on my desk, sunlight slanting through the window, promising peace. But just as I settled in, my phone buzzed: a last-minute delivery request. I hesitated, torn. As a delivery person, I was expected to respond promptly, to greet customers with a smile and hand over their packages with professionalism and warmth. But as a nun, I was supposed to honor my commitment to spiritual growth, to carve out time for prayer and contemplation. Now, standing at the customer’s door, I felt the weight of both roles. I forced a polite smile, but my mind was still in the quiet of my room, longing for the solace I’d planned. The customer chatted, expecting my full attention, while my heart wrestled with guilt for neglecting my spiritual duties. I wondered if I could truly serve both callings, or if I was failing at both.
